channel.title: C#/.NET - code protection? And advice on choosing between C++/C#
channel.description:
I would like to know how well can .NET code be protected from reverse engineering. There are various tools around. I'm new to this whole topic on .NET code protection. I found out that a tool called .NET Reactor actually prevents Dis# and .NET Reflector from being used to get the source code.
So I would actually like to know how efficient are the tools to protect .NET code and how efficient are the tools to reverse engineer it.
I would also like some advice on choosing between C++ and C#. I would go with C# if I get a positive reply here(that there are tools that make it impossible to get the source code) since I wouldn't be writing low-level applications. Otherwize I'll go the hard way and learn C++.
Thanks.

item.title: C#/.NET - code protection? And advice on choosing between C++/C#
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Tenen, post:8, topic:318030”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=414539.msg3052091#msg3052091 date=1260145468]
People who think they need to protect their code from other people stealing it almost invariably have never written code that anyone would want to steal.

But your best bet in an Open Source license, then you won’t have to worry about anything, and you will have a better product in the end.
[/quote]
http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html
<3[/quote]
opensrc != gpl. Use the BSD license/creative commons.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC

I’d go for open source. As long as you aren’t part of a group, you won’t be able to create anything that’s worth paying for.

item.title: C#/.NET - code protection? And advice on choosing between C++/C#
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security_through_obscurity#Arguments_against

Try this: don’t rely on security through making your binaries hard to reverse, make your code not suck.

And might I recommend, open source, and you have nothing to worry about.

Read full topic
